title: How to Make Frybread for Indian Tacos

steps.headline: Mix the yeast and water together and let it sit for 10 minutes.
Put in the salt, sugar, and the shortening in a very large bowl.
Add in the yeast/water mixture after the 10 minutes has gone by.
Add in another 2 cups of very warm water.
steps.description: Mix a little bit with a large spoon; don't worry if the shortening isn't totally melted/blended.

steps.headline: Add in 2 cups whole-wheat flour.
steps.description: Alternatively, use white flour for the whole thing - use whichever you prefer.

steps.headline: Stir well.
steps.description: Add in 2 cups of white flour and stir again. The mixture should start to become gloopy and follow the spoon around. Keep adding flour and stirring.

steps.headline: Turn the whole mixture out onto the counter/table when you can't stir with the spoon any more.
steps.description: At this point, start kneading the mixture and keep adding in flour, one cup at a time, up to maybe another 4-5 cups or so. Don't count the number of cups of flour you use, just work the dough until it has a good texture.

steps.headline: Keep using your hands and kneading in the flour until the dough stays together and stops feeling sticky.
steps.description: The dough should develop a slight sheen. It should still feel soft, not hard. If it's too hard, it won't rise very much.

steps.headline: Let it sit on the counter/table while you rinse out the mixing bowl after you're done kneading.
Put a light coating of cooking oil into the bowl you used, put in the dough, and then put a thin layer of cooking oil on the dough.
steps.description: Cover it with a dish towel and put it in a warm place to rise. Try putting in on top of the refrigerator - it tends to be warmer there.

steps.headline: Let the dough sit until it has doubled in size - this should take a couple of hours.
steps.description: Then, punch it in the middle and fold up the outer edges to the middle, flip it and cover and leave it to rest again, until it's doubled in size again.

steps.headline: Take it out of the bowl and break off pieces for the tacos, about 30.
steps.description: Roll them out on a counter/table that has been dusted lightly with flour. Roll the dough to about the size of a paper plate, and about ⁄8 inch (0.3 cm) thick. Let them rest whilst the cooking oil is heating up.

steps.headline: Test fry one small piece.
steps.description: It should turn slightly brown around the edges in about 15-20 seconds. Try using the tongs and press the dough down in the middle of it while it's frying, so it creates a small depression. Turn the piece over with tongs. Don’t leave the pan unattended, pay attention to it so you know when to get out the pieces.

steps.headline: Drain it on paper towels, then cover with a towel to keep warm.
Continue to fry pieces, drain, and cover.
steps.description: Enjoy as is, or with wojapi, syrup, peanut butter, jelly, powdered sugar, chilli, corn soup, or whatever your heart desires!

text: Mix the yeast and water together and let it sit for 10 minutes.  Put in the salt, sugar, and the shortening in a very large bowl.  Add in the yeast/water mixture after the 10 minutes has gone by.  Add in another 2 cups of very warm water. Mix a little bit with a large spoon; don't worry if the shortening isn't totally melted/blended. Add in 2 cups whole-wheat flour. Alternatively, use white flour for the whole thing - use whichever you prefer. Stir well. Add in 2 cups of white flour and stir again. The mixture should start to become gloopy and follow the spoon around. Keep adding flour and stirring. Turn the whole mixture out onto the counter/table when you can't stir with the spoon any more. At this point, start kneading the mixture and keep adding in flour, one cup at a time, up to maybe another 4-5 cups or so. Don't count the number of cups of flour you use, just work the dough until it has a good texture. Keep using your hands and kneading in the flour until the dough stays together and stops feeling sticky. The dough should develop a slight sheen. It should still feel soft, not hard. If it's too hard, it won't rise very much. Let it sit on the counter/table while you rinse out the mixing bowl after you're done kneading.  Put a light coating of cooking oil into the bowl you used, put in the dough, and then put a thin layer of cooking oil on the dough. Cover it with a dish towel and put it in a warm place to rise. Try putting in on top of the refrigerator - it tends to be warmer there. Let the dough sit until it has doubled in size - this should take a couple of hours. Then, punch it in the middle and fold up the outer edges to the middle, flip it and cover and leave it to rest again, until it's doubled in size again. Take it out of the bowl and break off pieces for the tacos, about 30. Roll them out on a counter/table that has been dusted lightly with flour. Roll the dough to about the size of a paper plate, and about ⁄8 inch (0.3 cm) thick. Let them rest whilst the cooking oil is heating up. Test fry one small piece. It should turn slightly brown around the edges in about 15-20 seconds. Try using the tongs and press the dough down in the middle of it while it's frying, so it creates a small depression. Turn the piece over with tongs. Don’t leave the pan unattended, pay attention to it so you know when to get out the pieces. Drain it on paper towels, then cover with a towel to keep warm.  Continue to fry pieces, drain, and cover. Enjoy as is, or with wojapi, syrup, peanut butter, jelly, powdered sugar, chilli, corn soup, or whatever your heart desires!
